eda_steps.step_description: Analysis of the class distribution across the three iris species to understand the balance and composition of the training dataset.
step_insights: Perfect class balance with exactly 40 samples per species (33.3% each)
No class imbalance issues requiring special handling techniques
Stratified sampling maintains original dataset proportions

dataset_description: The Iris dataset contains 120 training samples from R.A. Fisher's 1936 taxonomic classification paper, with measurements of sepal and petal dimensions for three iris species: setosa, versicolor, and virginica. This is a classic balanced dataset commonly used for demonstrating multi-class classification techniques.

columns.name: Id
columns.description: Unique identifier for each sample in the dataset
columns.additional_information: Not used for modeling purposes, serves as a row identifier

columns.name: SepalLengthCm
columns.description: Length of the sepal in centimeters
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature representing sepal length measurement

columns.name: SepalWidthCm
columns.description: Width of the sepal in centimeters
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature representing sepal width measurement

columns.name: PetalLengthCm
columns.description: Length of the petal in centimeters
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature representing petal length measurement

columns.name: PetalWidthCm
columns.description: Width of the petal in centimeters
columns.additional_information: Continuous numerical feature representing petal width measurement

columns.name: Species
columns.additional_information: Target variable with three classes: Iris-setosa, Iris-versicolor, and Iris-virginica

eda_summary: The Iris dataset is an ideal benchmark for multi-class classification with perfectly balanced classes and clean, numerical features. The training set contains 120 samples with no missing values, distributed equally across three iris species. All four features are continuous measurements of flower dimensions, likely requiring feature scaling for optimal model performance. The balanced nature eliminates the need for class imbalance handling techniques, making this a straightforward classification problem focused on feature relationships and model selection.
